column4: I want to install dapper using the graphical installer. however, ubuntu is started with 640x480 screen resolution, and the installer simply doesn't fit on the screen (I cannot press any OK/Next button since I don't see it). What can I do?
what wastrel said; also, try control-alt-+ to cycle through other available resolutions
higher screen resolutions are not configured
if your hardware can't do higher resolutions, then set up a virtual resolution that is higher than the real resolution
that way you can move around.  but alt-click is better if it does what you need
I was running every linux before on 1024x768
ok, then it isn't a hardware issue
I've seen that happen when the monitor is not automatically identified
it defaults to 640x480.  You can do dpkg-reconfigure for X and tell it what resolution your monitor is capable of
it isn't a card issue, it's most likely a monitor issue
even if it knows your card can do higher res, it won't do it unless it thinks your monitor can do so also
so do the reconfigure, then choose generic monitor 1280x960
ok. shouldn't the installer make me aware of the fact that 640 x 480 is a bit low, and should run dpkg-reconfigure automatically?
I don't know, I didn't write the installer  :)
eobanb: I reconfigured xserver-xorg, gave the default answer for every question, and now it runs at 1024x768. very strange

not entirely strange.  Most likely there are kernel modules loaded now, that were not loaded during the config during install, that let it ID the monitor, or the card, or whatever.  It recognized something it missed the first time around
